nodes.title: OMI Group Project Ideas - Nontechnical Discussion
nodes.body:
Below are some ideas for things I think the open interop metaverse needs. Many of them are or can be interconnected. They also stem from my own attempts at creating my own corner of the metaverse via a project I had called '[Flubbi](https://www.flubbiverse.com/)' a digital playdough system geared towards solving/addressing depression, loneliness, and poverty through powerful creativity tools. It was way too ambitious for my skillset, but it allowed me to explore these idea of the metaverse far beyond typical (sensible) limits. 

More importantly, I operated at a virtual reality arcade for over 3 years, and have been exploring the idea of XR and metaverse since elementary school. Working at the arcade allowed me to see what everyday people think about, have trouble with, and get excited about when they use this technology. From all of that and more I have thought about what would make the metaverse (or really the future of the internet) much more powerful, inclusive, and accessible. 

Anyways, please let me know which of these are things any of you might want to work on with me. Or if you have questions/feedback/resources and want to go into further detail. 

Without further ado, here are some of my ideas:

**Tools for creation** - Making it super easy (and fun) for non-technical and non-artistic people to create their own objects, avatars, and worlds. Something that goes beyond or at least is not _just_ one type of creative tool (like only using minecraft style or fortnite style or tilt brush style creation tools) so that people who prefer/are good at certain tools can find the one(s) that works best for them depending on their goals and skill level (ie meet them where they are, instead of forcing them to meet the tool where it is).

**Tools for simulation** - Ability to create (somewhat) realistic, immersive simulations on-demand. They don't have to be realistic in all ways, just a few for different contexts. For example: 
- space simulations for mapping stars or understanding planet dynamics, this can be used for creating an AR app that allows you to see past light pollution to get a better idea of the real night sky you are missing. Or to create cool skyboxes, or for VR space travel experiences
- biochemistry simulations for being able to visualize and communicate how vaccines work or how the immune system works; perhaps it can even show the dangers of microplastics, contaminated food/water, or the difference between good vs bad GMOs
- urban planning simulations that allows you to see the difference between a walkable city and a car-dependent one, thereby showing how much more freedom one has in a walkable city as opposed to a suburban wasteland. It can also allow one to scan your own neighborhood/city and begin simulating what it would be like if it was designed differently (ie better)
- physics simulations through either traditional physics-based engines or some sort of advanced voxel engines that can allow people to develop more interest sandbox games, or more interactive virtual worlds that you can explore in a headset or via traditional devices

**Virtual homes** - Your home away from home. Similar to the first idea, but focusing on the ability to host and access this home from anywhere, on any device, regardless of platform. This will really show people the value of being able to 'own' your digital life. It can be a way to visually access your stored data, talk to people or create content outside of any platform and their terms of service, and fully express one's creativity without the limitations of any one platform or medium. This should eventually be able to replace a person's homepage, desktop, and mobile device home screen such that 

**RSS but for any/all media** - Related to the above, but specifically about the ability to have content come to you, on your terms, rather than having to go elsewhere. You can bring in any type of content from anywhere on the web and either host/store it locally or at least access it directly (via embedding, iframes, or similar technology) divorced from the source platform's ad engine or algorythm suggestions. The interface one uses to manage all of this content (subscribing/unsubscribing, favorites, categories, ratings, shares, comments/notes, etc) should all be very flexible as well. You can design the interface exactly how you want it, or download templates and skins from others and remix those if you like too. You can even share your curated lists or subscribe to other curated feeds. Furthermore, you can download open source plugins/addons that help manage this information or even highlight bias, filter bubbles, dark patterns, and inaccurate information.

**Jailbreaker but for Interop** - Tool that can help you de-centralize yourself and break you out of closed gardens by porting all of your data (or as much as possible) from those places and into either your own hardware, p2p networks, or some other decentralized solution. Can walk you through the process or do it all automatically depending on your needs, budget, and source platform. The interface is similar to the above in that it is highly flexible, extensible, and accessible from any device or medium.

**Directory of Interoperability** - This has been brought by myself and many others in the early days of this project, but I wanted to give more details on what this can look like. We need to have an extensive list showing all the various tools, projects, papers, people, worlds, and so on that more or less follow our ideals around being open and interoperable. I'm sure many people have already had many of these ideas I've shared, and may even have built them out a good amount, but its extremely difficult to find them and get involved. So I'd like to do my best to help figure out a great information architecture and interface to finding, interacting with, and sharing these initiatives. Ideally, this directory should be accessible to all kinds of people, at all levels of technical knowledge, on all kinds of devices, especially immersive ones.
For example, what if we made directories that were:

- A 2D map, where you can see where to find everything in relation to others as if they were geographically located, this allows a somewhat easier way of remembering how to find information via spatial reasoning.
- A 3D map, that is similar to the 2D map, except you can be immersed in the map and see the indubitably more complex connections that a digital network has.
- A traditional directory, for all the folks that just want a simple list.
- A 3D immersive directory, where you can take something simple like a list and organize it in a way that makes sense to you in 3D space. This allows the use of more types of navigation (ie portals, pages, links, images, etc) and the manipulation of metadata in really interesting ways (ie being able to connect information together in unexpected but intriguing ways)

**Alt-Future Worlds** - This is more of an art/philosophy project to show people what it could look like to live in a different world. Too many people think that how things are today are just a 'necessary evil' or that anything else is 'unrealistic' or 'not practical'. But most of those people just suffer from a lack of knowledge on how things _were_ different and/or a lack of imagination on how things _can_ be different. Therefore, I'd like to help design different worlds (can be alt-history, positive scifi, or speculative fantasy), that help educate and inspire folks to think differently. Here are some ideas:

- Anarchist societies - Showcasing what living in anarchic communities actually looks like, along with informational blurbs pulled from anthropological data and present-day activism. 
- Solarpunk - Visualizing environments from aesthetic themes all the way to functional worlds, ranging from existing solarpunk fiction to the ability to craft one's own world in this vein.
- What if the world was never colonized - Alt-history worlds that show what it would be like to live in 'modern-day' aboriginal societies, explores the vast diversity in these societies from egalitarian foragers and cities to hegemonic, non-european empires.
- Space exploration without colonization - Exploring far future possibilities that go far beyond current-day assumptions of what humans might do when we have the ability to travel interstellar space; things like building space habitats, dealing with ethical considerations of interventions vs stealthy cataloguing and so on.
- The internet, but free - What would the internet look like if it wasn't monopolized by a few big tech companies? What if the original ideas of the internet that folks like Douglas Engelbart imagined.
- Digital public parks - Using data from folks like Civic Signals, what would it look like to have online 'playgrounds' that are in the Commons?
- Digital public libraries - Same as above, but for information/content sites. Also could be a modernization of current libraries
- Aboriginal societies, the reality - A heavily data-backed visualization of what indigenous societies were most likely like before colonisation.
- Hyperreality, non-dystopian version - Exploring what an ethical, well-designed, and positive 'hyperreality' could look like
- Metaverse, the non-dystopian dream - Re-imagining the idea of the metaverse based on crowdfunded ideas of what people first dreamt about the concept after reading them from dystopian fiction such as the Matrix, Snowcrash, and Ready Player One.


I know a lot of this is sort of wishlisting and is much harder to do IRL, also they are not all specifically about XR, but I think it is critical to develop these sorts of tools and ideas if we ever want to give as many people as possible a clear alternative to closed, data greedy platforms. I have been seeing and hearing so many people in the OMI community talk about all sorts of awesome stuff. I wish I could help more on the technical end, but my interests and skills(?) lie on this end, designing systems and ideating concepts based on human history, psychology, and dreams. 

I hope any of this is interesting and actionable to someone else. Because I'd love to go beyond just ideas and start turning this stuff into reality!

We want to approach sharing items, taking notes, and leaving breadcrumbs for those who couldn't attend by leveraging the github agendas comments feature. Instead of creating a separate note, lets keep notes here in the agenda comments. We want to make it easier for folks who couldn't attend to get up to speed. 

If you see something cool happening that someone is showcasing in discord on #hack-chat for example, please take a screenshot and paste it in the comments of _the next meetings agenda_. This can help ensure innovation is getting lost in discord threads, peoples accomplishments are shared early and often, and may even spark conversation in our meetings that we may otherwise have missed.
Please review our new documented ["OMI Github Strategy"](https://github.com/omigroup/website/issues/34) discussion.

nodes.title: 09/01/2021 Retrospective Reflection
nodes.body:
# Retrospective 1

Today in [Weekly Meeting 19]() we conducted our first retro as a group. Retrospectives provide a constructive way to take stock of what has been going well, what hasn't been going well, and what we could improve moving forward. Retros can take many forms, but the one we went with today can be accessed ~~on mural~~ [on figjam by figma](https://www.figma.com/file/RbJqQsQndOqZnPCWcHzMqW/OMI-Retro-090121?node-id=0%3A1)

## What's been going well
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63426722/131709108-6935417c-8d4a-423a-af8c-275dde800a98.png)

## What hasn't been working well? 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63426722/131709160-331d5703-d377-4f1c-ba3e-609d3626472e.png)

## What could we do better? 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63426722/131709249-eb6fe1c1-82cf-474d-952f-26b056ad28de.png)

In order to make some of these suggestions actionable, let's discuss these group* responses!
Migrated to figjam, I will be closing my Mural account for now as I can do 98% of what we need in figma or figjam :dagger:

nodes.title: Open Questions About Homeserver/Wallet Privacy
nodes.body:
Hey all, I wanted to add some interesting questions that have cropped up in the #OMI-Open-Inventory channel on Discord. 

**Shaw:** "I would like to see a zero knowledge scenario.
User syncs data with server A to local storage.
User goes to server B and gives permissioned access to data in local storage
Server B makes a hash of what is being claimed and sends it to server A for comparison
Server A confirms or denies it-- on denial the user can resync their local storage and try again
This way no user data ever flows between servers, in fact it isn't possible."

**Robert:** _"I'd love a more detailed proposal for this. I like the idea, but I'm not so sure that we can get adoption of zero knowledge APIs. Currently my thoughts are that a trusted home server is your protected data storage. You grant permission to other servers/applications to access partial views of that data. Scopes would be pretty granular.

Things like friends list access could even require a separate more serious permission method. Like, I would only want to give that permission to a browser extension / native app. It's more my client rather than an a third party application that gets access to a scoped view of my data.

**This is a bigger discussion that we need to have as a group though.** Who do we want to implement homeservers? Who do we want to integrate this into their app? What data do they need? What level of privacy can we build in without making it such that nobody will adopt it because it doesn't fit with their existing application's architecture?

You've also mentioned doing most of this work client-side. I'd love a view into what that would look like. I like this idea a lot, but need to see how it compares with a primarily homeserver-based implementation.

I'm super curious about this and have a bunch of questions. How does my wallet receive messages when I'm offline? Where does it store data? How does it sync between devices? Do we need a homeserver for this implementation? Is a homeserver just used for storage of encrypted data?"_
Software canisters on the Internet Computer blockchain might be a good medium for home servers.

@humbletim and I were talking and eventually, we may want to look out our Main (formerly known as "Master") backlog at the end of our meetings. This is where we can track what working groups we have, which projects are active, and which are for the future. 

If a topic gets removed from the agenda, it is often forgotten by the next week, because we usually copy and paste the agenda from the previous week. This may cause us to lose track of projects. We could explicitly state "We haven't seen any progress on the OMI place to meet, work, and hang, in about 4 weeks. So I am de-prioritizing #44 from active, to the backlog." And when a new topic gets added, we would explicitly state "We recently accepted proposal #49 and are moving this to active". 

That way when new topics are introduced we can ensure they are tracked/trackable. And when old topics fall to the wayside, we don't forget about them later. 

I am suggesting 5-10 min at the beginning or end of our Wednesday all-hands meetings. 

Thoughts?

Next week, let's start or end our meeting with a quick 15-20 min retro with those who can make it. 
- What has been going well? 
- What could be improved? 
- What could we do different moving forward? 

We will take 5 min to answer in a figjam board. And review for a timeboxed 10-15 minutes. We feed on actionable feedback.

nodes.title: OMI Identity on Element Matrix
nodes.body: Discuss and propose using Matrix Element for identity.

Press to open :point_down:
Log 2021-08-19 on Identity on Element Matrix

iFire — Yesterday at 13:31 @Robert for funsie you saw there's two matrix client libraries right? Robert — Yesterday at 13:31 There's actually quite a few iFire — Yesterday at 13:31 https://github.com/Sorunome/miitrix there's a second one Koolala — Yesterday at 13:32 I actually just now fell in love with ActivityPub since I read its all JSON Like a GLTF would possibly just work with it automatically cause its extensions are basically: is it described in JSON iFire — Yesterday at 13:33 https://github.com/Nheko-Reborn/mtxclient so both are the free-est extent of remixing. MIT or similar Robert — Yesterday at 13:34 ActivityPub and Matrix are both all JSON I'd take a look at the spec https://matrix.org/docs/spec/client_server/r0.6.1 Or here's one that lets you interact with a server via curl: https://matrix.org/docs/guides/client-server-api Matrix.org Client Server API | Matrix.org How to use the client-server API If you haven't already, get a homeserver up and running on https://localhost:8448 - e.g. by following the… You don't really need a client SDK, you could roll your own. It's a bit of work to get everything working like E2E encryption and message syncing, but it's doable. It's all HTTP based. ActivityPub is as well. The real differences are in the intended usecases. iFire — Yesterday at 13:38 Is it hard to support enough to get Robert's name and his avatar binary blob from an identfier? Robert — Yesterday at 13:39 ActivityPub was basically designed to be an federated alternative to social feeds like Twitter. Matrix was designed to be a federated chat/voip protocol. Robert — Yesterday at 13:39 Shouldn't be too hard https://matrix.org/docs/spec/#profiles https://matrix.org/docs/spec/client_server/r0.6.1#get-matrix-client-r0-profile-userid iFire — Yesterday at 13:41 You also mentioned a mailbox on your identity spec and @humbletim developed the concept of a friend is only when both contacts friend each other. Robert — Yesterday at 13:42 Yeah both Matrix and ActivityPub don't have a concrete method of friending eachother. iFire — Yesterday at 13:43 there's also merge into a group which a matrix room gives Robert — Yesterday at 13:43 Like you said, for activity pub, it's a mutual following. For Matrix, you just get the list of 1-1 rooms. You have to accept room invites anyway. It's not really the same as a friend. I guess you could set room information to say that this is a friend room though. And yeah you can represent groups as rooms as well. iFire — Yesterday at 13:44 There's the Japanese cultural concept of artist circles. Robert — Yesterday at 13:44 And then to notfiy a user/group you'd send it to all of their mailboxes in activity pub or the room in matrix. iFire — Yesterday at 13:45 and each object is signed by a retractable signature! by default Robert — Yesterday at 13:45 Yup they could even be encrypted in matrix ActivityPub may have a standard for that as well idk iFire — Yesterday at 13:48 the object signing should be acceptable by the blockchain crypto developers for use in whatever tech they want to use matrix signing for clarity is not on the blockchain which is what we promised we would do to not require blockchain like Eth or Bitcoin Koolala — Yesterday at 14:09 I wouldn't really be worried about intention or if its named a chat room or a feed or a message or a post but I'm curious to see what the overlap is with matrix and actpub just in terms of identity and organized communication over time iFire — Yesterday at 14:15 @Robert does matrix has a webfinger http json equiv? Robert — Yesterday at 14:18 In what sense? Email -> MatrixID? https://matrix.org/docs/spec/identity_service/r0.3.0#email-associations iFire — Yesterday at 14:19 url/MatrixID -> Name, GLB, Mailbox Robert — Yesterday at 14:19 That'd be this: https://matrix.org/docs/spec/client_server/r0.6.1#get-matrix-client-r0-profile-userid Server -> Server version: https://matrix.org/docs/spec/server_server/r0.1.4#get-matrix-federation-v1-query-profile iFire — Yesterday at 14:23 so in theory you can send me a matrix client http url for robert? Robert — Yesterday at 14:24 https://matrix.org/_matrix/client/r0/profile/@arobertlong:matrix.org iFire — Yesterday at 14:25 {"displayname":"Robert Long","avatar_url":"mxc://matrix.org/YsMmlvGvDByojlKdmOVEcnGT"} Robert — Yesterday at 14:25 Yup That's it Now if I can add my glb avatar to it, then we're good to go I think that could be added to the spec and Synapse for sure iFire — Yesterday at 14:26 there's private data section you linked to it 3.7 Profiles Users may publish arbitrary key/value data associated with their account - such as a human readable display name, a profile photo URL, contact information (email address, phone numbers, website URLs etc). 3.8 Private User Data Users may also store arbitrary private key/value data in their account - such as client preferences, or server configuration settings which lack any other dedicated API. The API is symmetrical to managing Profile data. Robert — Yesterday at 14:27 Yeah, I'd need to look into that more. I haven't looked closely yet. Koolala — Yesterday at 14:29 What parts of activitypub are you for sure confident of in their ability to overlap with Matrix? @Robert In a standard way Robert — Yesterday at 14:31 They overlap in that they both can sync federated lists of events. Events which can be extended in similar ways. They both provide identity, but Matrix also specifies possible authentication models. iFire — Yesterday at 14:32 Q? is the avatar binary blob completely open like the open web, or do each platform need to get it via capabilities. which requires rooms Robert — Yesterday at 14:32 Kinda up to us to figure that out I could see either. Idk, lots of stuff to figure out.

Thanks for posting this! Soon I'd like to get a more formal proposal together so we can talk about how platforms might utilize Matrix to build out realtime communications, identity, and permission systems.

  - Blender Tooling
  - Hubs -> OMI glTF Transform CLI
- Discord Bot
- World Exploration Meetup Recap

- Stellar Mesh

Add ons: 
- Evo suggested we talk about the nvidia announcement regarding [omniverse](https://80.lv/articles/nvidia-announces-a-major-expansion-of-nvidia-omniverse/)

Key part of nVidia Omniverse is the use of Pixar Universal Scene Description (USD) as the exchange format. They announced this week that Blender will support it.  They have bunch of announcements this week, including live talk while this meeting is happening (i think)
Don't forget showing off OMI-chan to everyone and asking for feedback, should take ~5 minutes

### Working agreements 
- if your working group would like to create a team working agreement, please reach out to Jesse (@mrmetaverse) for facilitation (if needed)
- We have found that creating a working agreement for all of OMI may not be ideal, as working agreements are best used for teams working on a specific topic. So for the gltf working group, or the upcoming stellar mesh working group, I recommend we draft working agreements that fit each teams. For example, we may have a working group consist mainly of people in Europe and they may want to establish standard working hours, or a standard toolset for workshops, etc. 
- Working agreements help strengthen team dynamics, and provide a psychologically safe place for all to participate. 
- Working agreements are also ideal for establish ceremony cadence, i.e. if your team wants to follow Scrum, you may want to establish a daily standup meeting time, a demo day, and a backlog refinement. But if your team doesn't want to use scrum, you may want to establish kanban or some other method of sharing and tracking work. 
- The most important part is that we should know how work gets done, how to get involved, and how to respect each other. 
-
Notes for todays session are started here on [hackmd](https://hackmd.io/@mrmetaverse/omi-081121)

nodes.title: World Building / Exploration Meetup 8/6/2021
nodes.body:
On Friday 8/6/2021 at 12:00 PM PDT we'd like to invite everyone to explore a few virtual worlds as we brainstorm ideas for OMI's virtual home.

The plan is to meet in Discord at noon PDT and check out Jel, other WebXR experiences, and whatever else we come up with. Meanwhile we'd like to take some notes for what platforms we'd like to build virtual OMI spaces for and how best to do so. We'll also be evaluating platforms for our future demo day.

Worlds to suggest visiting:
I mostly use FrameVR.io or Hubs with clients who need a quick web-based solution to work right now. 
Both teams seem open to future collaborations, especially Mozilla over Virbela for OS dev and interoperability. I personally have worlds in dev in both Spoke and Frame this month. 

I personally liked using New Art City but it may be too cumbersome for our v1.

Engage is picking up steam for edu uses, and Cause mentioned they're working on portability of worlds between Altspace and Engage (Christi recently took on the move of XR Social Club from VRChat to Altspace and has some thoughts/perspective to share on this). 

NeosVR is very open to hybrid and mixed world experiments overall along with Tvoli Cloud and our friends back in Second Life, especially at the Nonprofit Commons. All require downloads and are more heavy/cumbersome on your machines, not WebXR.

Nowhere is AFRAME on the web out of Brooklyn for small group streaming events and would work well for demo days, I have a room there that can host 20 people if anyone wants video meditated events without avatars (people appear as nonagons of their video presence in the AFRAME world). Nowhere generally has some cost to it but has provided me with a free room to use for meetups and testing. While in AFRAME, they're not primarily focused on interoperability; they serve artists & the virtual events industry. https://www.urnowhere.com/

The fiscal development working group met last week and the demo days came up, with a potential first date, and some early information which is summarized [here](https://github.com/omigroup/OMI/issues/59#issuecomment-885216344)

Reminder that we have Issue #59 : We are hoping to form an early group to plan what that first demo day might look like, how often we would meet, etc. Demo days are different than lightning talks, in that it is our chance to share our work with each other. As we continue to grow, it will become increasingly difficult to discuss all work being conducted in the allotted weekly sync timeframe. A system of regular demo days would help provide a sync for breakthroughs and challenges, and our weekly syncs can continue to be high level outcomes, and objectives. :dart: 

We have two working session scheduled for this Thursday already (I believe) so I'd like to suggest that we meet either this Friday or just after our weekly sync this Wednesday, to outline what we think a lightweight, and functional demo day process would look like. 

Other events, like hackathons, lightning talks, and events may require more unique planning, whereas this is our chance to make demo days slightly more systematic and drive both discovery and delivery backlogs from those sessions.

I propose that we discuss #68 : Defining our working agreement/playbook from our backlog around drafting a team working playbook (an agile working agreement). I understand that some may think that sounds like a legal document :sweat_smile: and I assure you, it's not. But they are important documents for teams working together. 

Working Playbooks/Agreements help us craft living documents that highlight where work happens, how we respect each other, how we prefer to be engaged, where we will escilate issues, etc. A really great format can be found here, and I am happy to faciltate any teams requiring a working agreement session. I recommend we create one for each working group / team, as preferences change based on team makeup.

I've got a late addition for the gltf-extensions topic: https://github.com/omigroup/three-omi

I've created a reference implementation of the OMI_audio_emitter proposal and set up this repository so we can quickly develop reference implementations of additional extensions. We could do the same for Godot or any other engine, or we can talk about other homes for these sorts of projects.

nodes.title: 7/14/2021 Weekly Meeting 12 Agenda / Discussion
nodes.body:
Weekly Meeting 12 is happening on Wednesday 7/14/2021 from 9:00 AM PDT - 10:00 AM PDT

You can add it to your calendar [here](https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1?cid=Y18wZHB1Z2Y5ZjgzZXE0cWVrbWI2b21xYmptZ0Bncm91cC5jYWxlbmRhci5nb29nbGUuY29t).

We'll be meeting again in the omi-weekly-meeting channel of the [AngellXR Discord](https://discord.gg/NJtT9grz5E).

## Agenda
- Website effort touchbase #49 
- GLTF extensions working group touch base #64 
- Fiscal Development Group touch base #57 

### Add-ons
- #59 
- #63 
- Jin would like to share some progress on incentive structures and discord tools for better online coordination

When we spend time together, we learn from each other. A critical part of our community development relies on our ability to communicate and document our findings. If you look at the agenda above, it's easier to see how our weekly meetings could soon lack enough time to discuss all of our working groups efforts. We would like to propose that a small team form to help plan the process for demo days where we will share our recent findings with each other. 

We created [ticket #59](https://github.com/omigroup/OMI/issues/59) to kick off the planning. We have a number of questions before we can press play. For example:
- how often should / can we meet? 
- how should we handle signing up to speak? 
- what is considered in and out of scope? 
- who can participate? 
- where do we document our findings for others? 
- is this actually going to be useful for our community? 
- how do we keep it lightweight and simple? This should be about sharing knowledge or recent lessons learned related to Interoperability, Open Source Metaverse, and OMI's work. _These are separate from lightning talks which can be about anything._ 

This conversation could take up an entire meeting, so I propose that we form a small team and plan the process before setting a date.

Today Robert and I created Issue #63 to create an "OMI weekly meeting discord bot". 

### Acceptance Criteria:
Takes attendance
Track voting

_Additional criteria can be tracked on the ticket [here](https://github.com/omigroup/OMI/issues/63)_

nodes.title: W3C Community Group Chair Nominations
nodes.body:
Nominate yourself or someone else for chairs for the Metaverse Interoperability W3C Community Group.

## What's involved with being a chair of a W3C Working Group?
These individuals will be responsible for making sure the group fulfills the [W3C's community group requirements](https://www.w3.org/community/about/process/#operational-agreements) as well as any of our group's operational agreements which we will also need to determine. Chairs will lead meetings, administer the GitHub repository, schedule meetings, send out agenda emails to the mailing list, and other administrative tasks.

## When will we be voting on chairs?
In the second meeting, we announced that we would hold an election on the 4th meeting. There's not a date set for that yet and we may push that date back should we not have enough candidates or diversity of applicants.

## How many chairs will there be?
Ideally we would only have 2-3 chairs. It could become somewhat challenging to manage more than a few chairs.

## How long is a chairs term? 
We believe that the first group of Chairs should serve for a 3 month term, at which time we will have another election. We believe we can increase term lengths as we grow. We believe this will help us become remain flexible, and diverse.
I nominate @robertlong
I nominate Jesse from AngellXR and Jin from Webaverse as both have shown a track record of commitment to the goal and ability to write things.
I can help support chairs with some experience from w3c [SocialWG](https://www.w3.org/wiki/Socialwg) or pull in advice from people who supported that group.

@dmitrizagidulin suggested in the W3C SocialCG call today that we might want to consider chair terms that increase in length as the community matures. Since OMI is such a young org - I agree with this suggestion. Many qualified people have yet to even hear about our group yet. If someone comes along in 3 months that would be perfect to help chair our group I think it'd be great if there was an election scheduled within a reasonable period of time to get them on board.

So perhaps we have our election within the next couple meetings? We elect 2-3 chairs and then in 3 months we do it again. After that one, we have another election in 6 months, then a year and then we can cap it at a year. Obviously these will be renewable terms and I would expect many people to be re-elected. 

We have some great people involved in this community and being proposed here. I'm not detracting from anyone's qualifications, but I think this group will change quickly over the next year or two and we will need the correct leadership to handle that.

Thoughts?

After our conversation in meeting 5, we'll be following a gradually increasing term duration for chairs. The first election tomorrow will have a term length of 3 months ending on the nearest weekly meeting (June 2nd - August 4th).
Before tomorrows vote, a few of us want to nominate Evo as a chair. <3

nodes.body:
Weekly Meeting 5 is happening on Wednesday 5/26/2021 from 9:00 AM PDT - 10:00 AM PDT

You can add it to your calendar [here](https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1?cid=Y18wZHB1Z2Y5ZjgzZXE0cWVrbWI2b21xYmptZ0Bncm91cC5jYWxlbmRhci5nb29nbGUuY29t).

We'll be meeting again in the omi-weekly-meeting channel of the [AngellXR Discord](https://discord.gg/NJtT9grz5E).

## Agenda
- Touch base on OKRs / OMI Core Values (10 min)
- Discuss setting up a monthly Retrospective for reflection, feedback, and iterative improvement (5min)
- [Chair Election Process](https://github.com/omigroup/OMI/discussions/17#discussioncomment-769909)
- [Identity Proposal](https://github.com/omigroup/OMI/issues/36)

Proposed from today (meet 4): Move OKR touch-base to next week. 

Also: I would also like to propose that we discuss implementing a Monthly 1-hour retrospective to establish a critical feedback loop to our organizational success: 
- What worked well for us?
- What did not work well for us?
- What actions can we take to improve our process going forward?

Any remaining time after the retro could be spent in the form of a _Lean Coffee style_ AMA/Open Discussion. In the absence of a Agile coach or Scrum Master, I would be happy to kick off the first few sessions until others feel comfortable facilitating as well.

I'd like to take some time to continue some of the discussions around Identity. We're getting some feedback in [this thread](https://github.com/omigroup/OMI/issues/36) and on the [ActivityPub SocialHub](https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks/t/minimum-viable-activitypub-implementation/1790), I think it's time to touch base and see how people are feeling. We can open the floor for anyone to discuss additional proposals on identity or ask questions / pose concerns on any of the solutions proposed so far.

Unfortunately, my recording for this meeting didn't correctly capture the audio. Here are some of my notes:

Identity:
- Fields in a person's profile should be able to be hidden unless made public. There was a discussion on whether or not visibility to friends is a good enough model for privacy.
- Permission prompts that detail what profile fields are being collected were discussed as a good way of permitting using user data.
- We discussed the possibility of avatars being represented as inventory items. Presumably the concepts of ownership, trading, and browsing them would be inherited from the inventory spec.
- Permissions for viewing a certain avatar/item could be represented in the inventory spec, making sure that you can tag an avatar/item as private or not.
- Avatars are often represented as multiple pieces, combined to form a single avatar. This could include different body styles, hair, clothing, and accessories. This could be stored as multiple glTF models and combined into a single one by engines. However, this is a pretty complex place to start and a single glTF/VRM model seems more achievable.
- We need the ability to have multiple identities. People represent themselves differently in different contexts, they may also may identity as [plural](https://pluralityresource.org/plurality-information/) and may front as multiple identities.
- It is incredibly important that identities cannot be publicly associated with each other if people wish for them to remain private. Protecting against fingerprinting is a difficult problem in XR where gait detection can accurately identify someone. While gait detection may be out of scope for an identity spec, we do need to keep fingerprinting and privacy in mind.

nodes.title: OKRs Q2 2021
nodes.body:
**EDIT: Date is set 05/05/21 6AM PDT and 6PM PDT:** 
Good morning. The OMI journey is both large in potential impact, and in contributors. We are looking to plan an OKR workshop to establish baseline Objectives and Key Results so that we may track our progress, as well as lay critical breadcrumbs for future contributors. 

**OKR's empower us with measurable goals**, however we are not expecting to achieve 100% of every OKR in a given quarter. OKRs encourage a flexible, and outcome driven mindset (rather than output driven). Our Objectives should tie directly to our overall vision, which I've taken a crack at crafting a first draft: _OMI's vision is to co-create an open set of standards for connecting the Metaverse. This includes it's users, stakeholders, and creators._ 

AngellXR is happy to facilitate this working session. We haven't set a date yet, and are still in planning. **Basically consider everything a draft, if you see an opportunity to improve something, please say something** 

We can drop OKR related readings and updates in this discussion thread. Cheers! 

Want to know more about OKRs? Check out this TED Talk from John Doerr: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4N1q4RNi9I 
_ideas are easy, execution is everything_

I support the idea of having concrete OKRs with a schedule.

Regarding the vision statement: At the risk of opening an unending semantic discussion, I haven't seen a solid consensus in the group about the meaning of "the Metaverse". Definitions range from "anything spatial on the Internet" to "teleporting myself and my inventory between first person immersive 3D platforms" and variations like "adding WebXR and payments to web pages".
Good resource: https://www.garyfox.co/okr-guide/

Would it be possible (practical) to conduct initial OKR workshops as two parallel groups? Specifically thinking about time zone coverage -- like if we offered _both_ 6am and 6pm workshops so at least one time occurs reasonably close to local daytime hours anywhere.

Ok based on some conversation, the 2 session option might be best rather than the 4 session option. 

I am available the following dates at **6AM PDT **and** 6PM PDT**: 
Friday 4/30/21 
Sunday 5/2/21
Monday 5/3/21 
Tuesday 5/4/21 
*Wednesday 5/5/21 (just added 4/27)

6AM - OKR part I (1.5 hours) - **Objectives**, we will work as a group to aggregate key objectives, organize by theme, and discuss expected or potentially measurable outcomes.

6PM - OKR part II (1.5 hours) - **Key Results**, we will resume from the efforts of the previous session, and this second group will assess the key themes, divide objectives into top-level, and specific-subset-level Objectives (the key here is top level, groups will have the option of setting sub-OKRs in alignment with these top level themes) Starting with the top level, we will discuss how we would know if we hit the given objective. What a lofty goal would be, and what a super "realistic" goal would be. We will repeat this process for the remaining items.

We will present the OKRs on GH discussions for all to review and take a vote after 24-48 hours. We will select an agreed upon number of OKR's, and teams can form around themes as needed. Teams will self assemble and establish Theme-specifc OKR's or epics that fit with our top-level OKRs.

Want to know more about OKRs? Check out this TED Talk from John Doerr: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4N1q4RNi9I
ideas are easy, execution is everything

That was a productive first session, thank you to those who were able to attend. We elected not to record the OKR sessions to promote psychological safety, and open discussion. The artifact can be viewed in figjam here: https://www.figma.com/file/VZZG4K3OigHdXxuWxKnuqU/OMi-OKR-Workshop-I?node-id=0%3A1

This evening (for me at least) we will establish high level themes, and how we will measure our success as a group. And then... its time to make magic happen!

### Happy Friday, Metaverse. 

We will continue the OKR workshop asynchronously until our next gathering. We made a lot of progress in our two sessions together. You can check out the Figjam space [here](https://www.figma.com/file/HcSUQRYUHjTcVyGIA0fu1u/OMi-OKR-Workshop-Part-II?node-id=0%3A1). [Figjam ](https://www.figma.com/figjam/)is a new collaborative whiteboard product from Figma.

The next step is to review our Objective statements. We made an effort to capture overarching themes from the thematic clusters we created in our workshop.  Please review and discuss, or if you have a suggestion for a great way to discuss each of these 5 themes in an organized way, please reach out! The 5 objective statements we have are as follows:

**1. We collaborate to make the metaverse more human.**

**2. We empower the people making the metaverse.** 

**3. We are creating a cooperative, sustainable culture of innovation.** 

**4. We incrementally deliver value, with intent.** 

**5. We must achieve resiliency through diversity, and freedom of choice.**

![OKR-omiObjectiveDrafts](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63426722/117510531-3a011900-af5a-11eb-8d0d-f17581e0165a.png)

Keep in mind, we are looking for _high level_, and _measurable_ objectives. Once we agree on a core set of objectives, we will begin describing how we know if we have achieved (or how we are progressing towards) an objective. Specific tactics, or "_hows_," and best practices most likely do not apply at this level. Those important concepts will apply at the execution level of these strategies and the tactics that are formed to achieve these objectives. 

We are also not looking for perfection. OKRs are not meant to be achieved 100%. If we score **.6** on a scale of  **0.0 - 1.0**, that is pretty good! We will revisit and refine our objectives every 3-4 months, and artifacts like our formal vision statement, and roadmap, will be informed by these high level goals we set as a fledgling organization. 

Please explore, and give these concepts great consideration. Is there something we are missing, or that can be refined? Do these make you feel inspired? 

Thank you for your commitment to this adventure together. 

For more information on OKR's check out "Measure What Matters: OKRs: The Simple Idea that Drives 10x Growth,"
 by John Doerr, or this article here: [link]( https://www.whatmatters.com/faqs/okr-meaning-definition-example/#:~:text=The%20definition%20of%20%E2%80%9COKRs%E2%80%9D%20is,encourage%20engagement%20around%20measurable%20goals 
)

Update: OKR's are now assembled in a single doc, and I am working on language now. Getting the information organized in such a way was the majority of the work. But now it's all ready for plugging in many of the themes we identified as a group. However, some of the key results are still missing. We have a good number of tasks, stories, and epic-fodder were crafted as a bi-product of our efforts. Now it's about making it all actionable and suited to our needs. 

I will keep working on this tonight, and hope we can review as a group for about 15-20 of this weeks session. We are so close! 

https://www.figma.com/file/VdJyo53j68SmGZbuApiE9Y/OMI-OKRs?node-id=2%3A25
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63426722/119376459-f4e32380-bc89-11eb-8d23-fa623ec73ccb.png)

nodes.title: Let's Explore: IDL (Interface Description Language)
nodes.body:
Collaborative research and development around using IDLs to capture and prototype interoperable data exchanges between platforms.

- initial experiments repo: https://github.com/XRFoundation/open-metaverse-interface @shawticus

brainstorming data elements to consider, @madjin shared a link the other day to [VRChat's API](https://vrchatapi.github.io/#).

similar to the draft experimental IDL schema, VRChat interfaces also differentiate (slightly) between the idea of the "current user" and other "user":
- User -- https://vrchatapi.github.io/#/Objects/User?id=user-object
- Base User -- https://vrchatapi.github.io/#/Objects/User?id=current-user-object

Loadout is an example of where we need some sort of flexible, possibly namespaced data. Some people will want loadout and some people won't.

If we want these concepts to be part of the spec, we could create archetypal interfaces that people can build on-- kind of like how ERC-721 can be implemented for all kinds of different features in NFTs. That way verses who choose to implement loadout can interface with the existing spec, if it's close enough to their own, or fork and create a new version (similar to IPSME).

nodes.title: Let's Share Links to Existing Standards and Specifications
nodes.body:
From the kickoff meetings and chats it seems like we ~all agree that we should use existing standards and specs when possible.

Let's use this discussion thread as a reference library of the metaverse-related standards and specs.

We won't use every single standard and spec listed here because we are doing something new. But, if we don't use a standard or spec then we should clearly know what the old work provided and why we don't want it. See [Chesterton's fence](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Chesterton%27s_fence).

- [Security Assertion Markup Language: SAML](https://wiki.oasis-open.org/security/FrontPage)
- [OAuth 2](https://oauth.net/2/)
- [W3C permissions](https://w3c.github.io/permissions/)
- [W3C trusted user interface](https://www.w3.org/Security/wiki/Trusted_User_Interface)
- [W3C security context UI](https://www.w3.org/TR/wsc-ui/)

- [Khronos glTF](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF/blob/master/README.md)
- [FBX](https://code.blender.org/2013/08/fbx-binary-file-format-specification/)
- [OBJ/MTL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_.obj_file)
- [Khronos COLLADA](https://www.khronos.org/collada/)
- [Pixar USD](https://graphics.pixar.com/usd/docs/index.html#IntroductiontoUSD-FurtherUSDresources)
- [Alembic](http://www.alembic.io/) Material Description Format

- [Web3d standards](https://www.web3d.org/standards): VRML, X3D, and HAnim
- [A-Frame](https://aframe.io/)

- [OWL time](https://www.w3.org/TR/owl-time/), 
- Geodetic datums like [WGS84](https://gisgeography.com/wgs84-world-geodetic-system/) and [GeoPose](https://github.com/opengeospatial/Geopose)

- [IPFS distributed storage](https://github.com/ipfs/specs)
- [WebDAV](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/WebDAV)

nodes.title: 5/12/2021 Weekly Meeting 3 Agenda / Discussion
nodes.body:
Hello everyone! Thank you to those that came out for our OKR workshop last week! It was totally worth waking up at 5:00 AM PDT for :sweat_smile: 

If you missed the last meeting, we came up with these objectives for OMI:

1. We collaborate to make the metaverse more human.

2. We empower the people making the metaverse.

3. We are creating a cooperative, sustainable culture of innovation.

4. We incrementally deliver value, with intent.

5. We must achieve resiliency through diversity, and freedom of choice.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1753624/117747633-6075bd00-b1c3-11eb-9e3e-56dc25c4b682.png)

This meeting wasn't recorded, but you can check out the full FigJam project [here](https://www.figma.com/file/HcSUQRYUHjTcVyGIA0fu1u/OMi-OKR-Workshop-Part-II?node-id=0%3A1).

## Agenda

Weekly Meeting 3 is happening on Wednesday 5/12/2021 from 9:00 AM PDT - 10:00 AM PDT

You can add it to your calendar [here](https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/1?cid=Y18wZHB1Z2Y5ZjgzZXE0cWVrbWI2b21xYmptZ0Bncm91cC5jYWxlbmRhci5nb29nbGUuY29t).

We'll be meeting again in the omi-weekly-meeting channel of the [AngellXR Discord](https://discord.gg/NJtT9grz5E).

We will be finishing our OKRs by defining key metrics for each of the 5 objectives. After that we'll go into our scope of work and discussing our proposal process.

After this meeting is the part where people get to start to start submitting their ideas for interoperability protocols and we get to figure out how we can start working together. For a lot of you, this next part is the part you've been waiting for and we thank you for your patience!

If you have other items that you'd like to add to the agenda please comment below and we'll get to everything we can. Give things a :+1: if you'd also like to see them on the agenda so we know what to prioritize.

Hope to see you all there!
Clarity around what we are looking for from the group for OMI W3C Chair nominations. What are we looking for, and what are the specifications of a Chair? (per our discussion)

Let's start with announcements and other agenda items before getting into KR's 

- W3C Chairs
- proposal process 
- Jin mentioned a NFT bot :) 
- when can we find time to have an open discussion about incentives

Then we will dive into KR's for the remaining time.

nodes.title: Incentives for Participating in OMI
nodes.body:
@madjin brought this up in our OKR workshop and there's been a lot of discussion on Discord since. How do we get people involved in OMI and keep them involved? It's a lot of work to develop specifications, lead meetings, and build prototypes. Why are we doing this? Why should we expect others to contribute? Are there financial incentives or is it more about shaping what we as a group think is the future we want to live in?

Jin also expressed interest in having a meeting in discord to discuss this synchronously. I think we should do that, but let's kick it off here and schedule and ad-hoc meeting so we can get into the nitty-gritty for those who are interested.

I'll start with why I'm involved. I'm doing this work because I think we need to from a moral perspective but also a financial perspective. I'd like to ensure that we are creating a new view into the internet that feels humane, not some dystopian view of cyberspace depicted in sci-fi novels. I'm also doing this work, because I want to work on projects in this space that would benefit from a more connected, open ecosystem rather than siloed, closed ones. I expect that is very similar to a lot of people in this group. I won't receive direct monetary gain from participating in these specifications, but the projects I'd like to work on can exist if we write them.

The larger players in this space are trying to establish their closed ecosystems where they set the rules and can push competitors out. In order for all our smaller projects to succeed, we need to work together. The network effects that we will receive from interoperability will lift us all up. I've already seen this with glTF. If your project can import/export glTF then you now have access to a massive content library. We need to continue creating interoperability points for identity and social systems so that the friction of joining our worlds and finding our friends goes down.

As to the the financial cost of participating in OMI, I get that these things take time. Each member will need to determine how much time they can realistically allocate to participating in our work. However, in many standards groups, you pay for membership. This is also a political group, we need to recognize that businesses are working together towards specifications, but we may also be competing for each-other's business. Co-operatition is a good thing! In our process, we will make many small decisions that could have huge effects on participants projects. Participating in OMI is exchanging time for influence. I mean all of this in the least cut-throat way possible, I think we're in this together for a set of shared goals, but if you need incentives, they are definitely already there.

Thanks a bunch for getting this thread started! I've written about my personal motivations and why I'm involved here in this blog post if interested: https://hackmd.io/@XR/motivation

[M3](https://github.com/m3-org/charter) had very similar goals and practices as OMI. As a founding member I helped to organize dozens of events with lightning talks (VODs: https://www.youtube.com/c/Exokit/videos), cross-platform field trips, and take notes for everything.

My experience of running M3 while also participating in web3 projects and DAOs has given me a unique perspective on how to structure mission driven communities to be more effective. This will be the subject of a future blog post, for now I'll share a few ideas in regards to this discussion:

**How do we get people involved in OMI and keep them involved?**

Having skin in the game is essential. As you mentioned even standards groups require membership dues. Many of the groups participating in w3c are companies which by extension are all value aligned themselves.

In M3 there was no shortage of amazing ideas that emerged from our discussions, what we needed is more coordination on execution. Shared ownership as a brand or organization brings about a sense of responsibility in fulfilling whatever role the member can do.

**Treasury**

Membership dues can go into a treasury for the organization. Having a treasury plays a role in coordinating the community. People can buy other members time in order to collaborate on a needed feature or more broadly for the promotion of our ideas.

**Recommendations**

- Keep track of the things people do
  - Can setup a discord channel (#did-a-thing)
- Decide on membership fees
  - Per month, season, annual, or lifetime
  - Anything is better than $0
- Outline paths to earn your way in
  - Note taking during meetings
  - Setting up a website
  - Designing swag / flyers
  - Contributing towards an OKR

**Crypto**

Blockchains are full of coordination games centered around shared data layers and open source software. Here's some recommended actions for easy ways for us to participate.

- Invite the NFT discord bot
  - We can mint/send tokens for free without needing to setup wallets
  - Tokens can represent achievements, tickets, or swag
  - It's been purpose built for organizations like OMI
- Matrix bridge Discord to Webaverse / Metafactory
  - Comms with communities implementing similar things
- Consider setting up a [Gitcoin](https://gitcoin.co/) page
  - Gitcoin Grants like crypto-style patreon, overall ~20M in results
  - Members can receive tips, projects can receive donations
  - Web3 / NFT projects are deeply invested in metaverse interop
    - Community that will champion us in public

nodes.title: W3C Metaverse Interoperability Community Group Charter
nodes.body: This is a placeholder for discussing and drafting up our community charter. I'd like for us to get through our next weekly meeting before we go into this. It'll also be closely related to our OKRs and scope of work.

nodes.title: OMI Scope of Work
nodes.body: For now this is going to be a placeholder discussion for the work we want to do in OMI. We'll discuss this more and outline a process for submitting proposals after our next weekly meeting.

nodes.title: Creating the OMI Community
nodes.body:
We've discussed how OMI will be structure for researching, extending, and promoting protocols/standards. However, we haven't really had a discussion around how we can engage our whole community. For those people who don't want to participate in technical discussions around protocols/standards, how can we make OMI a home for prototyping, research, and thoughtful discussion?

@jsealt and I have talked about having three different meetings:

1. Weekly W3C Community Group Meetings:
These meetings will be for discussing technical specifications for interoperability. We may split these up into meetings for each topic we're working on if they get to be too busy, but for now there will be one for all topics.

2. Bi-weekly Community Meetups:
The agenda for these meetings would be a community status update, an informal show-and-tell session, and a social gathering for anyone involved in metaverse projects. @madjin worked on a similar thing called Metaverse Makers Meetup (M3) that held meetings in various virtual worlds and celebrated metaverse makers. I'd like OMI to be able to continue this tradition.

3. Monthly Lightning Talks
We have a ton of people in our community working on amazing projects and with interesting backgrounds. This meeting would be a chance to feature them and educate our community on related topics.

Aside from these meetings, I think we need to discuss other ways we might want to work together as a community. Are there areas of research that we should be looking into? Are reference implementations of specifications enough open source work for OMI to house, or do people want to work on other types of projects? Should AngellXR house these efforts? @jsealt has expressed that Angell was basically set up for these sorts of projects. Also, do we need to create a separate non-profit organization from the W3C community group to fund research and development?

Increasing the scope of OMI comes with a cost. Managing an organization focused on standards/protocols is already a lot of work. I've heard a lot of interest for us to do more, but what can we realistically accomplish that will make OMI a great home for metaverse creators?

nodes.body:
Have a topic you'd like to share with the group? Pitch your topic below, and we will get you added to the list! 

Let's lift each other up, and learn together!

What is an NFT (I mean, actually, like in code) and how can we use them for interoperability? Contract deployment, gas, proof of work vs proof of stake, WTF is going on with Eth 2.0?, on-chain vs off-chain and resources to deploy your own NFTs.
I could do one on the work I did for Hubs on the glTF component data extension. This brings common object behaviors to glTF.

nodes.title: Service Design for adoptability of our efforts
nodes.body:
I would like to propose that we map some sort of Service Diagram or baseline artifact for understanding and empathizing with the actual level of adoptability of our efforts. Basically, what is the current standard process involved with building the Metaverse today, and are there opportunities to improve that process? Next, do any of our OMI efforts create new pain points, or solve new problems for these creators? 

I think I know what I am asking for, but this could use a research / content minded persons touch.

One example might be to explore how a standard should be optional. Like someone who writes scripts for video games may not want objects from other experiences entering their world, it may disrupt their intended narrative. Maybe others only want certain skins, or assets into their World, like a Western theme may be acceptable so no lasers. If adoption is too rigid it may not be attractive. _"What's the minimum effort necessary to contribute value?"_ is a question to ask while putting ourselves in other creators shoes. 

Another example might be around the Level of Effort of adopting any processes we come up with. Like if we make it more difficult to adopt a protocol, it may discourage its use.

nodes.title: W3C Community Group Proposal and Second Meeting Scheduling
nodes.body:
Hello everyone! Sunday's inaugural meeting was a huge success! We had over 35 attendees! I did not expect this level of interest this early, so thank you to everyone who showed up!

## Summary of the last meeting:

The meeting focused on getting to know each other, trying to define the "Open Metaverse", and figuring out how we want to organize ourselves.

There's a recording available here: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x3mFHxv9CNQ

And @madjin took notes which are available here:
https://hackmd.io/@XR/omi-1

## Action items from the meeting:

- Establish a GitHub organization for discussion and spec work (This org)
- Set up a Matrix room and bridges to existing Discord communities (I'm still working on this)
- Further investigate how we should organize ourselves and how we can work with/within existing organizations (W3C, DIF, Khronos, Matrix, etc.)
  - Gather information about W3C Community Groups
  - Determine if we can work with or be a part of an existing group 
  - Determine options for IP Protection
- Organize and present the data from the OMI Survey
- Schedule the next meeting based on the Doodle survey results

## Next Steps

Over the last week I've been speaking with different people involved in various W3C groups including @cwilso, @TrevorFSmith, @humbletim, and @dmitrizagidulin. I also attended the W3C Credentials Community Group's weekly meeting to get a sense for what they are working on there.

I received multiple recommendations for us to start our our own W3C Community Group. I think this is likely the best option for us. I did talk to @TrevorFSmith and @cwilso about possibly joining up with the W3C Immersive Web Community Group, but they are focused on lower-level browser API specifications such as WebXR, lighting estimation, hand tracking, etc. There is likely a lot that we can collaborate on, but it would be best for us to do this work in our own group with a sole focus on metaverse-related specifications.

You can read more about W3C Community Groups [here](https://www.w3.org/community/about/faq/).

I'd like to propose that we create a W3C Metaverse Interoperability Community Group for the purposes of developing specifications, holding discussions, and developing reference implementations.

The first step of this process is proposing a group on the [W3C website](https://www.w3.org/community/groups/propose_cg/):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1753624/114951721-d4fa4d80-9e09-11eb-8901-bcd5fccf1232.png)

We will need to decide on a name, description, and short name for the group.

Five individuals will then need to provide their support to the proposal by creating a W3C account and voting on their site. Pending W3C's approval we will then get a launch date for our group when we will be given access to the W3C Community Group infrastructure.

We will also need to nominate and vote on one or more community group chairs. These individuals will be responsible for making sure the group fulfills the [W3C's community group requirements](https://www.w3.org/community/about/process/#operational-agreements) as well as any of our group's operational agreements which we will also need to determine. There's a process for chair selection documented [here](https://w3c.github.io/cg-charter/CGCharter.html#chairs), but ultimately it's up to us to choose our own chairs.

Contributors to specifications will need to sign the [W3C Community Contributor License Agreement (CLA)](https://www.w3.org/community/about/process/cla/). This grants W3C royalty-free license to your individual contributions. You can read more about the IP protections [here](https://www.w3.org/community/about/process/#patents).

You also cannot participate in a community group anonymously. You must have an identity in the community and follow the [W3C Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct](https://www.w3.org/Consortium/cepc/). That also applies to all of our communications channels.

So, with all of that said. What will the activities of this group look like? We will propose and discuss specification work in this Github repository via Github issues. Specifications will get their own repository. Long form discussion, Q&A, and other topics dealing with public administrative work can happen in Github Discussions. We also will have both a public/private mailing list provided to us by W3C. I'd personally like to use these sparingly beyond meeting agendas, notes, and reminders. I'd opt for using github discussions and issues instead. Realtime communication will happen in our Matrix room, which I am still in the process of setting up due to our unique bridging requirements. Until then, we will continue meeting in the [AngellXR Discord](https://discord.gg/bnkTMCaRQe).

Specification and implementation repositories are something we can discuss in detail later. I still need some guidance on this, but I'll wait until we've decided on this group or not before we continue.

tldr; A W3C Community Group gives us a formal spec process, credibility when talking to larger companies, an IP protection framework that's already well understood and accepted by companies, and a bunch of resources that we can use.

I'd like to talk more about this here asynchronously so that everyone gets a chance to participate. I'd also like to schedule our next meeting where we can wrap up these discussions on the call.

Based off the Doodle Survey results, it looks like people are most available in the following time slots:
- Sundays 10:00 AM - 11:00 AM Pacific Time
- Sundays 11:00 AM - 12:00 PM Pacific Time
- Mondays 11:00 AM - 12:00 PM Pacific Time
- Mondays 12:00 PM - 1:00 PM Pacific Time
- Mondays 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM Pacific Time
- Mondays 5:00 PM - 6:00 PM Pacific Time
- Wednesdays 8:00 AM - 9:00 AM Pacific Time
- Wednesdays 10:00 AM - 11:00 AM Pacific Time
- Wednesdays 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM Pacific Time
- Thursdays 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM Pacific Time
- Thursdays 5:00 PM - 6:00 PM Pacific Time
- Thursdays 6:00 PM - 7:00 PM Pacific Time
- Fridays 8:00 AM - 9:00 AM Pacific Time
- Fridays 12:00 PM - 1:00 PM Pacific Time
- Fridays 1:00 PM - 2:00 PM Pacific Time
- Fridays 2:00 PM - 3:00 PM Pacific Time
- Saturdays 11:00 AM - 12:00 PM Pacific Time
- Saturdays 1:00 PM - 2:00 PM Pacific Time

We had 17 participants in that poll and it didn't narrow down the results enough so I'm going to create another with just these times.

# You can vote for the timeslots [here](https://doodle.com/poll/xt9b9t9zpwg7qkr9)

So now let's discuss this W3C Working Group Proposal, any objections, and the details for the proposal (name, shortname, description).

Thanks again for getting involved everyone!
AngellXR Discord invite seems invalid )

I'm about ready to close the availability poll for the next meeting. Monday 8:00 AM - 9:00 AM Pacific Time has the most votes, but I'm probably not going to be able to do that this week. I've got my second vaccine appointment the night before and I know the side effects can be rough.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1753624/115134544-f6a03400-9fc5-11eb-895b-23a25453dcdd.png)

I'd say we should shoot for one of the time slots with 8 votes. I'd like to propose we meet on Friday 12:00 PM - 1:00 PM PDT. That'll give us ample time to get the word out. I also think we can better accomplish things asynchronously here before the next meeting.

Our agenda for Friday will be to take a vote on forming this W3C Community Group, we also need to schedule a date and time for the [OKR workshop](https://github.com/omigroup/OMI/discussions/10).

Here's what we need:

- If you are in opposition to forming this W3C Community Group, please state your reasons and any alternatives.
- For the W3C Community Group Application we need:
  - A group name
  - A short group name used in urls/mailing lists
  - A description of the group that briefly explains our scope of work.
    - For example the Immersive Web Community Group's is:
      > Our goal is to help bring high-performance Virtual Reality and Augmented Reality to the open Web.
- Proposals for additional meeting agenda items. This is going to be a 1 hour meeting so please be conscious of the time. We'll try to get though as many things as we can.

Here's my proposal:

#### Group Name:
Metaverse Interoperability Group
#### Short Name:
metaverse-interop
#### Description:
Our mission is to bridge virtual worlds by designing and promoting protocols for identity, social graphs, inventory, and more.

Ok the final time for the meeting will be Friday, April 23rd 12:00 PM - 1:00 PM PDT.

We'll be meeting in Discord voice in the [AngellXR server](https://discord.gg/JRC8CvBUwR).

Thank you for organizing this!
